subject: thoughts to live by
verse: (Jesus cried) "My God, My God, why have You forsaken Me?" (Matthew 27:46)
reflection: Jesus was not questioning God; He was quoting the first line of Psalm 22 ~ it was a deep expression of the anguish He felt when He took on the sins of the world, which caused Him to be separated from His Father. Can I hear Jesus' cry of anguish and ever think lightly again of Sin? ~ Can I ever again fool myself into thinking that God might deal more lightly with Me than with His Son? ~ Better still, do I find rich comfort in Jesus' cry of anguish? ~ Do I hear my savior saying: Because God forsook Me, He won't forsake you. ~ Because God punished Me, He won't punish you. ~ Because God crushed Me under His anger, He will raise you up in love. ~ Because God rejected Me, He will receive you as His very own?
prayer: Dear Lord, Help me to never think lightly of my sins again. Help me to hear the cry of Your Son from the cross, and remember the price He had to pay for my sins. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "I have come that they might have life, and have it to the full" (John 10:10b
reflection: So swiftly life speeds by. So quickly it carries us to that gravestone with our names and two dates on it. ~ And between those two dates, only a dash to represent a short interval called life. ~ Is that all there is? If so, life's nothing more than a cruel joke, some dismal hoax, played on helpless mortals by an unfeeling deity. ~ If so, then better to have it over with quickly or to have never lived at all. But, Easter says, ~ "He is risen." ~ the grave is only the station where the believer's soul catches the early train while the body waits for the final train on the Last Day. It's not "goodbye" but "see you later" we speak to departing believers as we await the reunion with them in heaven. ."He is risen, " Easter says. But while He leaves us here on earth, it's not just that we might earn and eat, entertain and enjoy ourselves. Our daily, joyful mission is to live for Him and to shine with the light of Easter that others might stand in the light also. Yes, life on earth speeds by, but life in heaven lasts forever. And it's mine through the risen Jesus.
prayer: Thank You, Lord, for showing me the full life in the risen Savior. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: The disciples were overjoyed when they saw the Lord. (John 20:20)
reflection: Oh how afraid we can be of death! ~ We don't like going to the doctor because we're afraid he might find something that will end up killing us. We don't like talking about diseases such as cancer or heart trouble because they can often be fatal. Medicine that comes in a syringe or in a bottle may help keep us alive, but not forever. We need resurrection medicine. Where can we find it? The same place the disciples did that first Easter."They were overjoyed when they saw the Lord." For them resurrection medicine came in the form of the living Lord. ~ For us it is the written Word. ~ The saw the risen Jesus in person; we can see Him with the eyes of faith. Through the Word He stands before me, just as surely today as He did before the disciples in the locked room. Through the Word He speaks His promises of sin pardoned, death put to flight, and heaven flung wide open just as surely to me as to those first believers. We can get this resurrection medicine through regular dosages of His Word.
prayer: Dear Lord, fill me regularly with Your life-giving Word. Amen.

The risen Savior walked those two Emmaus disciples through the Old Testament Scriptures. ~ Everywhere He led them, they found His redemption of sinners."These are the Scriptures that testify about Me, " He once said (John 5:39) Now He taught those disciples how the humility of Christmas, ~ the pain of Calvary, ~ and the victory of Easter had been foretold by Moses and all the prophets. subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Then Jesus told them, "Blessed are those who have not seen and yet have believed." (John 20:29)
reflection: Some people think they would believe in Jesus if they could see a definite sign or miracle. ~ But Jesus says we are blessed if we can believe without seeing. We have all the proof we need in the words of the Bible and the testimony of believers. ~ A physical appearance would not make Jesus any more real to us than He is now. Luther wrote, "We should be careful not to follow our eyes. We should rather close our eyes and open our ears and hear the Word." Paul put it even better, "We live by faith, not by sight" (2 Corinthians 5:7). And Peter perhaps said it best of all, "Though you have not seen Him, you love Him; and believe in Him and are filled with an inexpressible and glorious joy" (1 Peter 1:8).
prayer: Dear Lord, give me the eyes of faith to see You in Your word as my living, all sufficient Savior. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: I am the Good Shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep. (John 10:11)
reflection: A certain pastor was calling his sermon title for the church notice in the newspaper. He dictated, "The Lord's my shepherd." ~ "Is that all?" asked the secretary on the other end of the line."That's enough, " replied the pastor. ~ Imagine his surpass when he opened the Saturday newspaper and read his sermon's title: "The Lord's my shepherd. that's enough." But oh how true! Jesus is the only shepherd we need. No one else can do what He did. He laid down His life for you and me. He thought of us when the agonies of Gethsemane pushed His soul into the dust. Of us He thought when the scourging cut His back. Of us He thought when the crown of thorns pierced His brow, and when the nails pinned Him to the tree. It's not enough for me to simply to say, "Jesus is a good shepherd." Not even enough to state, "Jesus is the Good Shepherd." When I by God's grace can say, "Jesus is my Good Shepherd, " Then I really have something. Then I have the gigantic difference between peace and turmoil, salvation and damnation, heaven and hell. Then I have the only shepherd I ever need.
prayer: Dear Lord, thank You for bleeding and dying for me. Thank You for giving me the faith to call You my Good Shepherd. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Surely goodness and love will follow me all the days of my life, and I will dwell in the house of the Lord forever. (Psalm 23:6)
reflection: Did you notice how David viewed the future? He spoke not in years, but days. Day by day he saw God's goodness and mercy following him. Actually, the Hebrew word he used for "follow" was much stronger. It meant to pursue, to chase after, catch up to, and clutch him. With goodness David referred to his shepherd taking care of his bodily needs. With love he pointed to the Shepherd's abiding love that provided forgiveness and strength for his soul. ~ Though David didn't know what the future held for him, he knew who held the future. ~ Wherever his Good Shepherd led, he could safely follow. So can I. Even when my last moment comes, I can follow His leading to the Father's house above. There I will be home forever with Him.
prayer: Dear Lord, surround me with Your goodness and mercy each day till you take me home, to be with You forever. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Obey the government, for God is the one who put it there. All governments have been placed in power by God. (Romans 13:1) ~ also check out (Psalm 75). I was challenged by a dear friend to read these verses. I'm so thankful for her.
reflection: Are there times when we should not obey the government? Yes? We should never allow the government to force us to disobey God. Jesus and His apostles never disobeyed the government for personal reasons: But when they did disobey, it was in order to follow God's moral standards. Their disobedience was not cheap: They were threatened, beaten, thrown into jail, tortured, and executed for their convictions. Like them, if we are compelled to disobey, we must be ready to accept the consequences. I'm inclined to believe the day is coming when we as Christians, will have to stand up and be counted. Let us remember to pray that we will be strong enough to remain faithful.
prayer: Dear Lord, Help me to remain faithful during the trials that are coming. Help all of Jesus' people to be willing to be counted for Him. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Jesus said, "Peace I leave with you: My peace I give to you. I do not give to you as the world gives. Do not let your hearts be troubled and do not be afraid.". (John 14:27)
reflection: There is very little real peace in the world today with all that is happening. We have wars and rumors of wars, earth quakes and volcanoes erupting, floods, tornadoes, financial melt downs, families loosing their homes, and their jobs, and scary decisions made by our Government, just to name a few things that cause us worry. But unlike worldly peace, which is usually defined as the absence of conflict, with Christ's peace, we have no need to fear the present or the future. If your life is full of stress, allow the Holy Spirit to fill you with Christ's peace. Read Philippians 4:6, 7 for more on experiencing God's peace.
prayer: Dear Lord, through Your Word remind me constantly of Your forgiveness so that I have peace. Amen.
